description: From Middle English moste ("must", literally, "had to", the past tense of Middle English moten (‚Äúto have to‚Äù)), from Old English m≈çste (‚Äúhad to‚Äù), 1st & 3rd person singular past tense of m≈çtan (‚Äúto be allowed, be able to, have the opportunity to, be compelled to, must, may‚Äù), from Proto-Germanic *m≈çtanƒÖ. Cognate with Dutch moest (‚Äúhad to‚Äù), German musste (‚Äúhad to‚Äù), Swedish m√•ste (‚Äúmust, have to, be obliged to‚Äù). More at mote.

entries.meaning: Something that is mandatory or required.
examples: If you're trekking all day, a map is a must.

verbs.description: must (third-person singular simple present must, no present participle, simple past must, no past participle)

entries.meaning: (modal auxiliary, defective) To do as a requirement; indicates that the sentence subject is required as an imperative or directive to execute the sentence predicate, with failure to do so resulting in a failure or negative consequence.
examples: You must arrive in class on time. (the requirement is an imperative)
This door handle must be rotated fully. (the requirement is a directive, necessary to operate the handle)

entries.meaning: (modal auxiliary, defective) To do with certainty; indicates that the speaker is certain that the subject will have executed the predicate.
examples: If it has rained all day, it must be very wet outside.
You picked one of two, and it wasn't the first: it must have been the second.

entries.meaning: (modal auxiliary, defective) Used to indicate that something is very likely, probable, or certain to be true.
examples: The children must be asleep by now.

description: From Middle English must, from Old English must and Old French must, most, both from Latin mustum.

entries.meaning: The property of being stale or musty.
Something that exhibits the property of being stale or musty.
Fruit juice that will ferment or has fermented, usually from grapes.
examples: No sweet grape lies hidden here in the shade of its vine-leaves,No fermenting must fills and o'erflows the deep vats.

verbs.description: must (third-person singular simple present musts, present participle musting, simple past and past participle musted)

examples: It was not, of course, a wild elephant, but a tame one which had gone ‚Äòmust‚Äô.
